sections: Just in case you haven‚Äôt noticed,
all the major Facebook services have been down

for some hours now. Not just the big blue site itself, but also Instagram and  WhatsApp, which not everyone realises is a Facebook property. Even my wife, who generally rejects all things social media, has noticed because she‚Äôs in several WhatsApp groups that have gone suddenly, blessedly quiet.

Twitter, which is still very much up, despite a few wobbles earlier, is full of memes and dunks on Facebook. In fact, for once, it's quite fun to be there. However, given that some publications depend
on Facebook for their traffic, this could actually be serious for them. As the hours tick by, and the traffic isn‚Äôt coming, they will be getting nervous‚Ä¶

So, it turns out that having three of the biggest services on the internet owned by the same company and run on the same infrastructure might not be the best idea in the world. It‚Äôs turned a resilient system into a fragile one. Everyone who has come to rely on this singular company‚Äôs services will be suffering tonight.
And it‚Äôs our own damn fault.

. It‚Äôs designed to route around points of failure. And in the early, more Wild West years, it boomed because of that. Our internet experience was a mess of websites and blogs and chat rooms and email discussion lists. But slowly, over time, that changed. Well-funded businesses
, and locked up great chunks of human communication for their own financial benefit.

And nobody has been better at that than Mark Zuckerberg. He‚Äôs slowly rebuilt the internet within his own walled garden, and many of us have followed him into there. We‚Äôve allowed ourselves ‚Äî both as businesses and as individuals ‚Äî to become dependent on these centralised services. With that centralisation has come user convenience ‚Äî but increased fragility.
Anyone can send an email to anyone else. But WhatsApp being down has choked off a whole bunch of conversations.

And tonight, many businesses are paying the price of falling for the Zuckerberg seduction. If you‚Äôre a retailer whose sales mainly come through Instagram ‚Äî you‚Äôre losing money. If you‚Äôre an influencer who is paid for collabs on these platforms ‚Äî well, you‚Äôre scheduled posts aren‚Äôt going to be doing you much good today.

If you‚Äôre in the audience team of a publication heavily dependent on Facebook for traffic ‚Äî I feel for you. But you‚Äôre also the architect of your own misfortune because you‚Äôve let yourself become dependent on a single source of traffic
And rule 1 of audience strategy is this:
diversify your acquisition and engagement channels as widely as you can
Now, it‚Äôs easy to dunk on Facebook. It‚Äôs been
something of a fortnight for it‚Ä¶
But other platforms are just as bad.

If you‚Äôre a successful YouTuber, or a publisher that earns substantial revenue from the platform, imagine YouTube going down for 12 hours. How much is that going to cost you in lost revenue? If your traffic is driven solely by search, imagine Google going down for half a day. How does that help you meet your targets?

More realistically, imagine a major algorithm shift on the platform. That can ‚Äî and has ‚Äî killed businesses in the past, both on Facebook and on Google. And then think about how Substack is manoeuvring to make itself the central hub for all things newsletter, and think a little more about central points of failure‚Ä¶

For all the amusing dunking on Facebook happening on Twitter right now, there‚Äôs a serious lesson underlying today‚Äôs impact. Never, ever rely on a single company for your traffic, your community or your comms. Diversify the hell out of your reader acquisition and your reader engagement. Think of back-up channels and alternative ways of reaching people when something falls over.
Whenever one tool ‚Äî be it search, or social, or even newsletters ‚Äî becomes too dominant, put time and effort into balancing your mix.

A publication with a healthy mix of acquisition and engagement channels is a sustainable one. A business dependent on a single channel only exists at the whim of that platform ‚Äî and of the skill of the technologists who run it.
